concepts.concept_name: Sources of food: plants and animals
Food from plants: fruits, vegetables, grains, spices
Food from animals: milk, eggs, meat, honey
Cooking methods and why we cook food
Food preservation: keeping food fresh and safe

in_scope: Plants give us fruits, vegetables, cereals, pulses, oil, spices
Animals give us milk, eggs, meat, honey, fish
Some foods are eaten raw (fruits, salads) and some are cooked
Cooking methods: boiling, frying, roasting, baking, steaming
Cooking makes food soft, tasty, and kills germs
Food preservation: refrigeration, drying, pickling, adding salt/sugar
Indian food examples: roti, dal, rice, sabzi, curd, paneer, idli
out_of_scope: Detailed nutrients (carbohydrates, proteins, fats) - Introduced in Class 4
Balanced diet and food pyramid - Introduced in Class 4
Vitamins and minerals in detail - Introduced in Class 5
Deficiency diseases - Introduced in Class 5

concepts.concept_name: Animal habitats: where different animals live
Bird beaks, claws, and feet: adaptations for food and movement
Bird nests: types and materials used
Animal migration and seasonal movement
Caring for animals and birds around us

in_scope: Habitats: forest, desert, water, grassland, polar regions
Indian animals: tiger, elephant, peacock, camel, monkey
Beaks: strong (parrot), long (woodpecker), flat (duck), sharp (eagle)
Claws and feet: webbed feet (duck), sharp claws (eagle), hooves (horse)
Bird nests: tailor bird sews leaves, weaver bird weaves grass, woodpecker makes hole in tree
Migration: birds travel long distances when seasons change
Siberian crane visits India in winter
We should not harm animals, provide water and food for birds
out_of_scope: Detailed animal classification - Introduced in Class 4
Food chains and food webs - Introduced in Class 4
Animal reproduction - Introduced in Class 5
Endangered species in detail - Introduced in Class 5

concepts.concept_name: Seed germination: how seeds grow into plants
Types of plants: herbs, shrubs, trees, climbers, creepers
Plant adaptations: how plants survive in different places
Importance of trees and forests

in_scope: Seeds need water, air, warmth, and soil to grow
Germination: seed coat breaks, root grows down, shoot grows up
Herbs: small, soft stems (tulsi, mint, coriander)
Shrubs: medium-sized, hard stems (rose, hibiscus)
Trees: tall, thick trunk (neem, banyan, mango)
Climbers: need support to climb (money plant, grapevine)
Creepers: spread on the ground (pumpkin, watermelon)
Desert plants: thick stems, no leaves or spines (cactus)
Water plants: float or grow in water (lotus, hydrilla)
Trees give oxygen, shade, fruits, wood, medicines
out_of_scope: Photosynthesis process - Introduced in Class 4
Plant reproduction details - Introduced in Class 5
Plant cell structure - Introduced in Class 6

concepts.concept_name: Water cycle: evaporation, condensation, and precipitation
Sources of water: rivers, lakes, wells, rain
Water conservation: saving water in daily life
Water purification: making water safe to drink

in_scope: Sun heats water, water turns into water vapour (evaporation)
Water vapour rises, cools, and forms clouds (condensation)
Water falls from clouds as rain, snow, or hail (precipitation)
Sources: rivers, lakes, ponds, wells, tube wells, rain
Underground water: wells and hand pumps
Save water: turn off taps, fix leaks, use bucket instead of shower
Rainwater harvesting: collecting rain water for later use
Water purification: boiling, filtering, using water purifier
We should not waste or pollute water
out_of_scope: States of matter in detail - Introduced in Class 4
Water treatment plants - Introduced in Class 5
Groundwater systems - Introduced in Class 5
Water pollution in detail - Introduced in Class 5

concepts.concept_name: Different types of houses and shelters
Building materials used for houses
Houses in different regions of India
Why we need shelter and what makes a good home

in_scope: Types: kutcha house, pucca house, flat, bungalow, hut, tent, houseboat
Building materials: bricks, cement, wood, bamboo, mud, straw, stone
Houses protect us from heat, cold, rain, wind, animals, and thieves
Igloos in snowy places, stilted houses in flood areas
Houseboats in Kashmir, bamboo houses in Assam
Mud houses in villages, concrete buildings in cities
Tents used by nomads and at construction sites
Houses should have proper ventilation, sunlight, and clean surroundings
out_of_scope: Architectural details - Not covered at this level
City planning and infrastructure - Introduced in Class 5
Construction engineering - Not covered at primary level

concepts.concept_name: Clean surroundings and hygiene
Waste management: types of waste and disposal
Reduce, Reuse, Recycle (3Rs)
Taking care of our environment

in_scope: Keep surroundings clean: no littering, use dustbins
Dirty surroundings attract flies, mosquitoes, and cause diseases
Wet waste: vegetable peels, food scraps (biodegradable)
Dry waste: plastic, glass, metal, paper (non-biodegradable)
Reduce: use less plastic, carry cloth bags
Reuse: use old bottles, jars, and containers again
Recycle: paper, plastic, and glass can be made into new things
Plant trees, do not cut trees, keep parks clean
Swachh Bharat Abhiyan: keeping India clean
out_of_scope: Global warming and climate change - Introduced in Class 5
Detailed pollution types - Introduced in Class 4
Industrial waste management - Introduced in Class 6
Ozone layer - Introduced in Class 7

concepts.concept_name: Road safety rules and traffic signals
Fire safety: prevention and what to do in a fire
Basic first aid for common injuries
Personal safety: good touch and bad touch awareness

in_scope: Road safety: walk on footpath, use zebra crossing, look both sides
Traffic lights: red means stop, yellow means wait, green means go
Always wear seatbelt in car, helmet on bicycle or scooter
Fire safety: do not play with matchsticks, candles, or gas stove
In case of fire: shout for help, call fire brigade, crawl low in smoke
First aid for cuts: wash with clean water, apply antiseptic, bandage
First aid for burns: put under cold running water
First aid for insect bite: wash area, apply soothing cream
Good touch: hugs from parents, pat on back from teacher
Bad touch: any touch that makes you uncomfortable or scared
Say NO, run away, and tell a trusted adult if someone gives bad touch
out_of_scope: Advanced first aid and CPR - Not covered at this level
Detailed traffic laws - Introduced in Class 5
Disaster management - Introduced in Class 6

concepts.concept_name: Types of families: joint family and nuclear family
Family members and their roles
Caring for each other in a family
Family tree: understanding family relationships

in_scope: Nuclear family: parents and their children living together
Joint family: grandparents, parents, uncles, aunts, and cousins living together
Family members: grandparents, parents, siblings, uncle, aunt, cousins
Roles: parents earn and take care, grandparents guide and share stories
Children help at home: keeping room clean, helping in kitchen, studying well
Caring: sharing, helping when someone is sick, celebrating festivals together
Family tree: a chart showing how family members are related
Relationships: maternal and paternal grandparents, siblings
out_of_scope: Legal definitions of family - Not covered at this level
Family laws and inheritance - Not covered at primary level
Complex genealogy - Not covered at this level

concepts.concept_name: States and union territories of India
Languages and diversity of India
National symbols of India
Festivals and cultural diversity

in_scope: India has 28 states and 8 union territories
Capital of India is New Delhi
Many languages: Hindi, English, Tamil, Bengali, Telugu, Marathi, and more
National flag: saffron, white, green with Ashoka Chakra
National anthem: Jana Gana Mana, written by Rabindranath Tagore
National bird: Peacock, national animal: Tiger, national flower: Lotus
National emblem: Ashoka Pillar with four lions
Unity in diversity: different languages, clothes, food, festivals but one nation
Major festivals: Diwali, Eid, Christmas, Holi, Pongal, Baisakhi, Onam
out_of_scope: Detailed political geography and all state capitals - Introduced in Class 4
Indian constitution and government - Introduced in Class 5
Detailed history of India - Introduced in Class 5

concepts.concept_name: Four main directions: North, South, East, West
Simple maps and what they show
Landmarks and finding places
Reading and drawing simple maps

in_scope: Four main directions: North, South, East, West
Sun rises in the East and sets in the West
If you face North, South is behind you, East is to your right, West is to your left
A map shows places from above, like a bird's eye view
Maps use symbols to show roads, buildings, rivers, parks
Landmarks: well-known places that help us find our way (school, hospital, post office)
Simple neighbourhood maps showing roads and important places
Left, right, straight, turn, near, far — basic direction words
out_of_scope: Map scales and coordinates - Introduced in Class 5
Latitude and longitude - Introduced in Class 6
Compass rose and intermediate directions in detail - Introduced in Class 4
Topographic maps - Not covered at primary level

concepts.concept_name: Different occupations and what people do
Why people work and how work helps the community
Dignity of labour: respecting all kinds of work
Rural and urban life: village and city

in_scope: Occupations: farmer, teacher, doctor, police, postman, carpenter, tailor, cobbler
Tools used by different workers: stethoscope (doctor), plough (farmer), chalk (teacher)
People work to earn money, help others, and serve the community
All work is important: no job is big or small
We should respect every worker — sweeper, helper, driver, guard
Village life: farming, open spaces, ponds, fewer vehicles
City life: offices, factories, tall buildings, more traffic, markets
Community helpers: people who help us in daily life
out_of_scope: Economic concepts and income - Not covered at this level
Labour laws and child labour - Introduced in Class 5
Industrial sectors (primary, secondary, tertiary) - Introduced in Class 6

concepts.concept_name: Evolution of transport: from animals to modern vehicles
Types of modern transport: land, water, and air
Indian Railways and public transport in India
Road safety rules for travellers

in_scope: Early transport: walking, animals (horse, camel, donkey, elephant, bullock cart)
Invention of wheel changed transport forever
Land transport: bus, car, auto-rickshaw, bicycle, train, metro, truck
Water transport: boat, ship, steamer, ferry
Air transport: aeroplane, helicopter
Indian Railways: one of the largest railway networks in the world
Public transport: bus, train, metro — used by many people
Road safety: use zebra crossing, wear helmet, fasten seatbelt, follow signals
out_of_scope: Engines and fuel types in detail - Introduced in Class 5
History of aviation - Introduced in Class 5
Space transport - Introduced in Class 6
Detailed mechanics of vehicles - Not covered at primary level

concepts.concept_name: Means of communication: old and new
Letters, telephone, and personal communication
Internet and digital communication
Mass media: newspaper, radio, and television

in_scope: Communication means sharing information, ideas, and feelings
Old ways: messengers, pigeons, drums, smoke signals, letters
Letters: written on paper, put in envelope, posted at post office
Telephone: talk to people far away using phone
Mobile phone: can talk, send messages, take photos, use internet
Internet: email, video calls, chat — fast communication across the world
Mass media: newspaper, radio, television — reach many people at once
Post office and postman: deliver letters and parcels
Safe use of internet: do not share personal information with strangers
out_of_scope: Satellite communication - Introduced in Class 5
History of internet in detail - Introduced in Class 6
Coding and programming - Introduced in Class 5
Social media in detail - Not covered at primary level
